BC-BKN-SUNS-MAVERICKS-AZR 
SUNS' FORTUNE TIED TO MAVS'MISFOR TUNE 

   (For use by N.Y. Times News Service clients)  
 By NORM FRAUENHEIM  
 c.1999 The Arizona Republic  

   PHOENIX - The Dallas Mavericks have been called Suns East and
the Phoenix junior varsity. The two teams have more links than some
families have cousins.

   Suns guard George McCloud has a home in Dallas. Mavericks
forward Cedric Ceballos has one in Phoenix.

   But these days, the Suns and Mavericks are linked by more than
just a shared past. Their respective futures also are tied to one
another in what could become an interesting tug of war between
ex-colleagues.

   It's a rivalry, all right. The stakes were created by a trade
last July, when the Suns acquired forward Pat Garrity and an
unconditional first-round draft pick for playmaker Steve Nash.

   The key is the draft pick.

   The jury is out on Garrity. He's shown some promise, but it's
impossible to judge a rookie based on nine games.

   Nash, a third-year guard, struggled through Dallas' first eight
games. In a loss Friday to Golden State and a victory Saturday over
the Los Angeles Clippers, he began to play with the efficiency of
last year, when he was a backup to Jason Kidd and Kevin Johnson.
Nash is still trying to adjust to a new team in an abbreviated
season after the chaotic NBA lockout.

   ``I think I maybe didn't realize what a tough situation this
is,'' said Nash, who faces former Phoenix teammates tonight in his
first return to America West Arena since the trade. ``We had two
weeks of training camp before we saw what was going to happen in a
game, and then, it's like wildfire.

   ``This reminds me of my rookie year (1996-97) in Phoenix when we
started 0-13. This team has a lot more life than that team. But
it's going to be a tough season.''

   Nash struggled with a foot injury during the off-season and then
missed 40 of his first 50 attempts from the floor. He since has hit
on 14 of 22 attempts and displayed floor leadership that was a key
to the Mavericks' first two victories. It's early, but he doesn't
get the free pass given to Garrity.

   Fair or not, Nash's playmaking ability will determine whether
the Suns get a lottery pick (No. 1 through No. 13) or a choice late
in the first round of the next draft. If he plays better, the
Mavericks figure to win more. The more the Mavericks win, the later
the Suns will pick.

   So Nash is still an important part of the Suns' future. But this
time, the Suns will be hoping for turnovers instead of assists.

   The Suns have the option of giving the pick from Dallas or their
own to the Chicago Bulls to complete the Luc Longley trade. They
also can wait until 2000 to give the Bulls a first-round pick.

   At this stage it looks as if the Bulls will have to wait. The
potential for a lottery pick has not gone unnoticed by the Suns.
Fact is, it was there long before Nash ever put on a Mavericks
uniform.

   The Mavericks have not been in the playoffs for eight years _ a
futility streak that is the NBA's longest. There's a solid chance
it will grow to nine. The Mavericks are 2-9.

   The Suns have adjusted their scouting strategy in the event of
pick among the first 13.

   ``It changes a little bit,'' said Dick Van Arsdale, the Suns'
senior vice president for player personnel. ``We're not looking at
it as though we might be able to find a player who could slip to
the 25th pick. We're looking for somebody who can play now. There's
a chance we could have a top pick.''

   As the college season nears March Madness, the Suns' scouting
process is in high gear. The club already is judging players
according to how they fit the Suns' needs.

   ``We're being more specific,'' Suns scout Al Bianchi said.
``We're zeroing in on the type of guys we might want.''

   After just nine games, the Suns have found themselves to be
without the sort of dynamic, athletic talent provided by Antonio
McDyess, who left Phoenix for Denver. There might not be a McDyess
among the current college prospects, but there are great leapers
and shooters.

   ``The big guys, all seniors, are players we've pretty much put
on the back burner,'' Van Arsdale said. ``We're looking at the
first 10 to 15 players. We like the Kobe Bryants of the world.''

   Van Arsdale was referring to Bryant's athletic talent and not
his lack of college experience. The Suns are unlikely to expend a
high pick on high school players. Their immaturity and uncertain
development make the investment too risky.

   But there are some intriguing prospects in the colleges.

   Some names: Rhode Island small forward Lamar Odom, Auburn
swingman Chris Porter, Duke power forward Elton Brand, Maryland
guard Steve Francis and Connecticut guard Richard Hamilton.

   ``With a top-five pick, you'd probably get a good player, one
who could play right away,'' Bianchi said.

   But, for now, it all depends on what Dallas does.

   Or doesn't do.
